Between 11 September 2019 and 31 October 2019, what will be the widest closing spread of the yield on 10-year Treasurys below the yield on 2-year Treasurys? Being late to the party sometimes has advantages.
The spread has risen to 21 bps today. Both yields have been rising in tandem, in spite of expectations of Fed lowering benchmark rates on Wednesday. Already baked into the markets??

for most of October their were cracks appearing in the international economy so there was still a chance that the yield curve could invert. However recent strength in Germany and a purported US/China deal has reduced that possibility to negligible for this time frame.

The 10-2 year treasury spread yield is 0.19 % as of today. 10 year treasuries continue to out perform 2 year treasuries. Notwithstanding the uncertainty of Brexit. While this will continue to play out over the week, I'll revise up to 100 %. That 10 year yield will not close at or less than 2 year yields by 31 October.
Updating for current level and time left.

My current extrapolations suggest that there is little chance of the spread closing below the 2 yr yield - unless there is a jump due to some surprise in the bond market that my TES model can't capture. My model says 100% that the 10 yr will not close <= than the 2 year. However, I'm leaving my forecast the same because stating 0% probability for 10 below 2 is saying that I think it is impossible. Using a version of Sherman Kent's WEP Probability scale, I think the 10 yr bond is almost certain to close above the 2 year (ie, positive spread), but it is not impossible to be surprised.

4 days to ~15%.

The spread is barely 12 bps positive with 3 weeks to go. Chairman Powell seems to want to intervene on the very short end by buying short Treasuries to provide overnight bank liquidity, and also reducing the reference rate. Interestingly, the 10-yr/3-month spread is indeed negative, with the 3-month rate at 1.71% and the 10-year at 1.532%. This spread has been negative since late May - i think more from the demand by banks for overnight/short money (evidenced by bills) for reasons I do not fully understand---as it seems more of an accounting/balancing the books nightly kind-of-thing. If Powell is able to influence the very short end - it should ripple up into the two-year ---- but that is a pretty long way up the yield curve - and I don't know how tight the correlation is between a move in the bills and the 2-year yield. Nevertheless - incremental changes that this spread will not go negative.

The Fed is going to restart Open Market purchases to increase reserves in order to prevent challenges in the repo market. Powell indicated that these purchases will focus on the short end of the yield curve. https://www.wsj.com/articles/powell-says-federal-reserve-will-soon-announce-measures-to-increase-supply-of-bank-reserves-11570559401?emailToken=f468a029c20ee812b5a8784e229fecb5+VXoEY6Ka4jVgX3jx+o45N3iqtWg/6UwR5qmB9dO+71aDMga3bTh+DTrN7JlIgjLy6KvXYEnM4mJQtQxiBRlgEu40ljBlzdo9TAmqdF6CaKRd3tx+38HdL50ASmHXxeZXIk5fK6ZpvnJ13vrdKkXa8VdOnzsWJxvSKLDTLv4gZU%3D&reflink=article_copyURL_share On the surface, this will lower short term yields, while an expected rate cut (81% probability according to FedWatch) will raise long term rates.

Still an abnormally tight spread historically. For purposes of the question, 12 bps is a world away from inverted yields. Nevertheless - we have a whole month of fun and fury that can tip this any which way.

Curve steepened a bunch yesterday into today. Spread now stands at 11 bps up from 4 just a few days ago. Weaker stock market and economic data increases the odds of Fed cutting on 10/30. That is currently weaving it's way into expectations and is being reflected in the steeper curve.

I look at the spreads for historical periods. These are currently at levels close to zero, so using percentage change of spreads would yield volatile numbers. Hence I use change of spreads over past periods. I look at both weekly change and daily change. There are 5 weeks from now to 2019 Oct 31st, or 25 trading days.

The inverted nature of the yield curve tends to be an indicator of global economic pessimism. The recent pessimism has been a function of the volatile trade talks between the US and its trading partners. The US administration has now given the indication that trade agreements may be coming sooner than later. If this is true, and further evidence presents itself in corroborating this, then pessimism should ease for the remainder of the year.
he 10 yr has not yet closed below the 2 yr yield. Currently, the spread is 4 basis points with the yields 1.77 and 1.73 respectively.

the majority of the time the 10 year yield is higher than the 2 year. Though there are many clouds on the economic horizon leading indicators are not showing too much stress. Also, the odds should be on a positive US/China resolution trade resolution. Finally, the Fed rate cut yesterday provides some stimulus which should provide upward momentum to longer term yields as opposed to short term.(though that is not the case this morning)

Note to start: Fellow forecasters, is it just me or are the answer options for this question not collectively exhaustive? The way I see it, if the 10 yr yield closes at the 2 year yield and that is the lowest spread in the question timeframe, none of the answers apply. Granted, since 1990 there have only been 21 days on which the 10yr yield closed at the 2yr yield, or 0.28% of days, but nevertheless, it happens. Please let me know your thoughts.

Need to do some deeper analysis, but upticks in the stock market are not being reflected in bonds and a bubble seems to exist in US debt that is causing negative real yields. I think aggressive easing by the Fed is supporting the long end of the curve, but there are still technical factors (duration and convexity hedging) at play that could keep yields low. Trade was risks also persist. My base case is for an inversion given fundamentals, trade worries, and demand for US debt. Looking at this based on the current state of China. Significant unrest in HK, political tensions escalating domestically, the West using China's unrest as a point of leverage by demonizing China for their treatment of citizens and exacerbating the issue , China's focus shifting between domestic issues and trade tensions with US.

We currently have a +.053 spread - no yield curve inversion. It follows a substantial reversal from the -.053 spread of Aug 26 or so. Both the 2-year and the 10-year have now had their yields move strongly and suddenly upwards since Sep 4/5. This reversal feels like "risk-on" by traders more than it does any statement either way about the economy. Using TLT (20-year treasuries) as my guide - we're at a level of support presently at 139.50 - but it played weakly today. I'm no technician - but next level of support seems to be 130 - which translates to a yield of 2.68% from today's 2.49% if TLT continues to fall in price this week and next. And if TLT does continue to fall in price, I'd expect the 10-year yield to move upwards in similar fashion, while the two-year rate will be biased downwards because of Fed rate cutting. Thus, a likelihood of continued positive spread through Oct 31. Let's see what happens.....

Official forecasts of recession that I respect are still below 25%. The inversion seems to have been an overreaction to trade tensions. Current spread is 7 basis points, up from a negative reading only days ago. With only weeks to go in the question, I think a double-digit spread is a good bet.
